ACE.description: ACE observes particles of solar, interplanetary, interstellar, and galactic origins, spanning the energy range from solar wind ions to galactic cosmic ray nuclei.
ACE.name: Advanced Composition Explorer

AIM.description: AIM is dedicated to the study of noctilucent or “night-shining” clouds (NLCs) also called Polar Mesospheric clouds (PMCs), also called noctilucent clouds, to find out why they form and why they are changing.
AIM.name: Aeronomy of Ice in the Mesosphere Satellite

AM1.description: Terra is designed to monitor the state of Earth's environment and ongoing changes in its climate system. It's five state-of-the-art sensors have been studying the interactions among the Earth's atmosphere, lands, and radiant energy.
AM1.name: Terra

AQUA.description: The satellite has six different Earth-observing instruments collecting data about our Earth's water cycle, including evaporation from the oceans, water vapor in the atmosphere, clouds, precipitation, soil moisture, sea ice, land ice, and snow cover on the land and ice.
AQUA.name: Aqua

AURA.description: Aura's four instruments obtain measurements of ozone, aerosols and key gases throughout the atmosphere.
AURA.name: Aura

CO1.description: Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC) is a program designed to provide advances in meteorology, ionospheric research, climatology, and space weather by using GPS satellites in conjunction with low Earth orbiting (LEO) satellites.
CO1.name: COSMIC-1

CO2.description: Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC) is a program designed to provide advances in meteorology, ionospheric research, climatology, and space weather by using GPS satellites in conjunction with low Earth orbiting (LEO) satellites.
CO2.name: COSMIC-2

CO3.description: Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC) is a program designed to provide advances in meteorology, ionospheric research, climatology, and space weather by using GPS satellites in conjunction with low Earth orbiting (LEO) satellites.
CO3.name: COSMIC-3

CO4.description: Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC) is a program designed to provide advances in meteorology, ionospheric research, climatology, and space weather by using GPS satellites in conjunction with low Earth orbiting (LEO) satellites.
CO4.name: COSMIC-4

CO5.description: Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC) is a program designed to provide advances in meteorology, ionospheric research, climatology, and space weather by using GPS satellites in conjunction with low Earth orbiting (LEO) satellites.
CO5.name: COSMIC-5

CO6.description: Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC) is a program designed to provide advances in meteorology, ionospheric research, climatology, and space weather by using GPS satellites in conjunction with low Earth orbiting (LEO) satellites.
CO6.name: COSMIC-6

COBE.description: COBE revolutionized our understanding of the early cosmos by precisely measuring and mapping the oldest light in the universe -- the cosmic microwave background. The results confirmed the Big Bang theory of the origin of the universe.
COBE.name: Cosmic Background Explorer

DSCOVR.description: DSCOVR is observing and providing advance warning of particles and magnetic fields emitted by the sun which can affect power grids, communication systems, and satellites close to Earth.
DSCOVR.name: Deep Space Climate Observatory

EO1.description: The EO-1 mission includes three advanced land imaging instruments and five revolutionary cross cutting spacecraft technologies. The hyperspectral instrument is the first of its kind to provide images of land-surface in more than 220 spectral colors.
EO1.name: Earth Observing-1

FGST.description: This exciting mission has revolutionized our understanding of the cosmos by observing the universe in gamma-rays, the most energetic kind of light. Thanks to Fermi, scientists have learned more about fundamental physics of the cosmos, from dark matter to the nature of space-time and beyond.
FGST.name: Fermi

GALEX.description: The Galaxy Evolution Explorer was an orbiting space telescope designed to observe the universe in ultraviolet wavelengths to measure the history of star formation in the universe.
GALEX.name: Galaxy Evolution Explorer

GOES-14.description: GOES satellites have provided continuous imagery and data on atmospheric conditions and solar activity (space weather), and have led to more accurate and timely weather forecasts.
GOES-14.name: Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite 14

GOES-15.description: GOES satellites have provided continuous imagery and data on atmospheric conditions and solar activity (space weather), and have led to more accurate and timely weather forecasts.
GOES-15.name: Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite 15

GOES-16.description: GOES satellites have provided continuous imagery and data on atmospheric conditions and solar activity (space weather), and have led to more accurate and timely weather forecasts.
GOES-16.name: Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite 16

GOES-17.description: GOES satellites have provided continuous imagery and data on atmospheric conditions and solar activity (space weather), and have led to more accurate and timely weather forecasts.
GOES-17.name: Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite 17

GPB.description: Gravity Probe B (GP-B) confirmed two key predictions of Albert Einstein’s theory of relativity, the geodetic effect and frame-dragging, indicating that both space and time are distorted by the presence of massive objects.
GPB.name: Gravity Probe B

GPM.description: An International satellite mission to provide next-generation observations of rain and snow worldwide every three hours.
GPM.name: Global Precipitation Measurement

HESSI.description: Explore the physics of particle acceleration and energy release in solar flares
HESSI.name: Reuven Ramaty High Energy Solar Spectroscopic Imager

HST.description: Hubble is a space telescope launched into low Earth orbit in 1990, and remains in operation. Although not the first space telescope, Hubble is one of the largest and most versatile, and is well known as both a vital research tool and a public relations boon for astronomy.
HST.name: Hubble Space Telescope

IBEX.description: IBEX is helping us discover the nature of the interactions between the solar wind and the interstellar medium at the edge of our solar system.
IBEX.name: Interstellar Boundary Explorer

IC2.description: ICESat-2 (Ice, Cloud and land Elevation Satellite) uses a spacebourne sensor to collect altimetry data of the Earth's surface optimized to measure ice sheet elevation change and sea ice thickness, while also generating an estimate of global vegetation biomass.
IC2.name: ICESat-2

ICON.description: Designed to investigate the forces at play in the near-space environment, leading the way in understanding disturbances that can lead to severe interference with communications and GPS signals.
ICON.name: Ionospheric Connection Explorer

IMAGE.description: IMAGE was the first sattelite mission dedicated to measuring the Earth's magnetosphere. IMAGE was recently re-discovered 13 years after failing to respond in 2005.
IMAGE.name: Imager for Magnetopause-to-Aurora Global Exploration

IRIS.description: IRIS observes how solar material moves, gathers energy, and heats up as it travels through a little-understood region in the sun's lower atmosphere.
IRIS.name: Interface Region Imaging Spectrograph

ISS.description: The international space station, or a habitable artificial satellite, in low Earth orbit. It is the size of a football field and serves as a microgravity and space environment research lab where crew members conduct experiments in biology, human biology, physics, astronomy, meteorology, and other fields.
ISS.name: International Space Station

JA2.description: Jason 2 is an Earth satellite designed to make observations of ocean topography for investigations into sea-level rise and the relationship between ocean circulation and climate change.
JA2.name: JASON 2

LAD.description: LADEE orbits the moon to gather detailed information about the lunar atmosphere, conditions near the surface and environmental influences on lunar dust to help scientists understand planetary bodies.
LAD.name: Lunar Atmosphere and Dust Environment Explorer

LRO.description: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter is a NASA robotic spacecraft currently orbiting the Moon. Data collected by LRO is essential for planing future human and robotic missions to the moon.
LRO.name: Lunar Recon Orbiter

LS7.description: Landsat is observing and measuring Earth's continental and coastal landscapes at a scale where human impacts and natural changes can be monitored, differentiated, and characterized over time.
LS7.name: LANDSAT-7

LS8.description: Landsat is observing and measuring Earth's continental and coastal landscapes at a scale where human impacts and natural changes can be monitored, differentiated, and characterized over time.
LS8.name: LANDSAT-8

MEA.description: The Metop satellites are series of satellites dedicated to near-real-time operational meteorology observations.
MEA.name: Metop-A

MEB.description: The Metop satellites are series of satellites dedicated to near-real-time operational meteorology observations.
MEB.name: Metop-B

MEC.description: The Metop satellites are series of satellites dedicated to near-real-time operational meteorology observations.
MEC.name: Metop-C

MMS.description: MMS consists of four identical spacecraft that investigate how the Sun's and Earth's magnetic fields connect and disconnect, explosively transferring energy from one to the other.
MMS.name: Magnetospheric Multiscale Mission

NPP.description: NPP provides atmospheric and sea surface temperatures, humidity sounding, land and ocean biological productivity, and cloud and aerosol properties to help us understand, monitor, and predict the course of long-term climate change AND short-term weather conditions.
NPP.name: Suomi National Polar-orbiting Parn

NUSTAR.description: This is the first orbiting telescopes to focus light in the high energy X-ray region of the electromagnetic spectrum, which helps us study collapsed stars, black holes, and supernova remnants.
NUSTAR.name: Nuclear Spectroscopic Telescope Array

OCO-2.description: Orbiting Carbon Observatory (OCO)-2 is NASA's first dedicated Earth remote sensing satellite to study atmospheric carbon dioxide from space.
OCO-2.name: Orbiting Carbon Observatory 2

OR7.description: Cygnus Commercial Resupply Services (CRS) missions are ISS cargo resupply missions using Orbital ATK's Cygnus spacecraft.
OR7.name: Cygnus CRS OA-7

QUIKSCAT.description: QuikSCAT mission is intended to record sea-surface wind speed and direction data under all weather and cloud conditions over Earth's oceans.
QUIKSCAT.name: QuikSCAT

SCISAT.description: SCISAT helps a team of Canadian and international scientists improve their understanding of the depletion of the ozone layer, with a special emphasis on the changes occurring over Canada and in the Arctic.
SCISAT.name: SCISAT

SMAP.description: Soil Moisture Active Passive is an orbiting observatory measuring the amount of water in the top 5 cm of soil everywhere on the Earth's surface.
SMAP.name: Soil Moisture Active Passive

SOLAR-B.description: SOLAR-B is a highly sophisticated observational satellite equipped with three advanced solar telescopes to explore the magnetic fields of the Sun.  It consists of a coordinated set of optical, extreme ultraviolet (EUV), and x-ray instruments to investigate the interaction between the Sun's magnetic field and it's corona.
SOLAR-B.name: Hinode

SORCE.description: SORCE measures incoming X-ray, ultraviolet, visible, near-infrared, and total solar radiation to understand how the sun affects our climate.
SORCE.name: Solar Radiation and Climate Experiment

SOYUZ.description: The Soyuz carries people and supplies to and from the international space station.
SOYUZ.name: SOYUZ

STPSAT-5.description: STPSat-5 satellite helps advance the DOD’s understanding of the space environment, which will enable and support the development of future national security space systems for the United States.
STPSAT-5.name: Space Test Program Sat-5

SWAS.description: SWAS studies the chemical composition, energy balance and structure of interstellar clouds and the processes that lead to the formation of stars and planets.
SWAS.name: Submillimeter Wave Astronomy Satellite

SWIFT.description: A first-of-its-kind multi-wavelength observatory dedicated to the study of gamma-ray burst (GRB) science.  Its three instruments work together to observe GRBs and afterglows in the gamma-ray, S-ray, ultraviolet, and optical wavebands.
SWIFT.name: Swift

TDRS-1.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-1.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-10.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-10.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-11.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-11.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-12.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-12.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-13.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-13.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-3.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-3.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-4.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-4.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-5.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-5.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-6.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-6.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-7.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-7.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-8.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-8.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

TDRS-9.description: TDRS satellites are part of a collection of geosynchronous telecommunications satellites that support NASA Missions with the transmission of data to the ground.
TDRS-9.name: Tracking and Data Relay Satellite

THA.description: Aims to determine what physical process in near-Earth space initiates the violent eruptions of the aurora that occur during substorms in the Earth's magnetosphere.
THA.name: THEMIS-A

THB.description: THEMIS aims to determine what physical process in near-Earth space initiates the violent eruptions of the aurora that occur during substorms in the Earth's magnetosphere.
THB.name: THEMIS-B

THC.description: THEMIS aims to determine what physical process in near-Earth space initiates the violent eruptions of the aurora that occur during substorms in the Earth's magnetosphere.
THC.name: THEMIS-C

THD.description: THEMIS aims to determine what physical process in near-Earth space initiates the violent eruptions of the aurora that occur during substorms in the Earth's magnetosphere.
THD.name: THEMIS-D

THE.description: THEMIS aims to determine what physical process in near-Earth space initiates the violent eruptions of the aurora that occur during substorms in the Earth's magnetosphere.
THE.name: THEMIS-E

TRACE.description: TRACE is a satellite mission designed to deepen understanding of our dynamic sun’s activity, by exploring the connections between fine-scale magnetic fields and the associated grand-scale plasma structures on the sun.
TRACE.name: Transition Region and Coronal Explorer

TRMM.description: The Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission was a joint space mission between NASA and the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency designed to monitor and study tropical rainfall.
TRMM.name: Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission

WIRE.description: WIRE was originally designed to study startbusrt galaxies, but failed soon after launch due to a malfunction that caused the space telescope's coolant to be rapidly depleted. It did, however, reach Earth orbit and was instead used for astroseismology, which involved measuring the oscillations of nearby stars to examine their structure.
WIRE.name: Wide-Field Infrared Explorer
